The atomic world is admittedly weird.  Not all of it "makes sense."  Richard Feynman once said "If you think you understand quantum mechanics, you don't understand quantum mechanics."  Much of it simply is not intuitive and seems foreign from the macro world we experience.  How can multiple options for the atomic overlap occur simultaneously?  I have no idea, but we have a large body of evidence leading us to conclude that it does. And there are others.  There is still some debate of what the two-slit experiment with electrons ultimately means.  If an electron in a 'p' orbital has zero probability of being found in the nucleus, but can be found on either side, how does it get from one side to the other...again, i have no idea, but it does.  Ultimately, you running into a question here that even I can't answer, but I can tell that you are indeed grasping the oddity we call quantum mechanics.😊

If it helps to memorize the orbital diagram I have drawn here, the pi* orbital is below the σ* orbital meaning it is lower in energy. When we consider the bonding orbitals, σ orbitals align head on whereas pi align side by side, meaning σ orbitals overlap more than pi orbitals. For in phase this leads to greater constructive interference for σ bonding orbitals than pi bonding orbitals making σ lower in energy. Howerver, for antibonding orbitals that are out of phase we have the opposite effect - σ* overlap head on causing greater destructive interference than pi* orbitals and therefore the σ* is higher than energy than pi*... hope that helps!

is it something that can be measured?

The volume of the molecular orbital.  Bonding molecular orbitals result from constructive overlap and result in greater volume compared to the corresponding antibonding molecular orbitals which result from destructive overlap.  So the volume of the bonding MO is greater than the volume of the corresponding antibonding MO and this also contributes (to a small extent) to the lower energy of the bonding MO according to the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle.

Very approachable. Amazingly good actually, as I followed it all and I'm not even a chemist. I did physics and maths, dropping chemistry quite early on. Two nitpicks: In the first few minutes the term mathematical 'equation' was used instead of 'function'. At 26:22 it is stated that processes tend to minimise the energy of the universe. It is more a question of maximising the entropy of the universe. Energy is conserved. The decrease in molecular energy has to be reflected by an increase in the energy of the rest of the universe. Entropy, though, is not conserved and increases when energy is distributed throughout the whole universe. These momentary remarks are very much a side issue here and do not detract at all from the value of this video.

Or is it that only atoms which are either perfectly in phase or out of phase bond at all?

(caveat: I'm not an expert, but I do have some conceptual understanding of the underlying quantum mechanics)  Yes, you can in fact pick "intermediate" combinations if you like. And then you dove into the underlying quantum mechanics, you could formulate the physics of the molecule in terms of these alternative "orbitals", and it would be equally valid! But you can only pick two at a time. Once you pick any two different combinations, those two will already span the space of the possible molecular electron orbitals at those low energy levels. Then, any further choices are redundant - any other "orbital" at those low energies would simply already be a linear combination (including possibly a shifting of phase) of the two combinations you picked.  This is analogous to how if you're trying to orient yourself in 2D space, and a-priori there isn't an "X axis" and a "Y axis" defined, you can freely pick what direction you choose to call "X" and then can freely pick any different direction to call "Y" (ideally a direction perpendicular to X, but you could even pick "skew" axes if you want!). Then after that, there isn't any more room for a third axis. Any third direction you pick within the same 2D space would just be some combination of the two you already picked. Still, any choice of X and Y would be equally valid and let you navigate.  In the case of the molecular orbital here, however, any of the "intermediate" choices of combinations between "completely in phase" and "completely out of phase" are not constant in energy. In quantum mechanical terms, you can work out that they aren't eigenfunctions of the wave equation for the electrons around the molecule. This means that although you could pick any two intermediate combinations as you describe to be your "orbitals", and it would be equally valid as a physical description of the electrons around the molecule, the occupation of these "alternative" orbitals by the elections would constantly appear to be changing and oscillating in a complex way. It wouldn't let you easily analyze the stability of the bonding of the molecule, because what matters for the bonding stability is the energy level of the electrons, and these alternative "orbitals" wouldn't correspond to single clean energy levels.  To draw a loose analogy with the 2D space again - suppose the 2D space you're trying to navigate is a city, whose city blocks are laid out in a strict rectangular grid of streets and avenues. Imagine you chose your X and Y axis to be directions that were skewed and misaligned with the city grid. Mathematically, it would be equally valid to express the motions of cars within the city grid in your alternative system, but it would be more complex. A car changing its "street" coordinate while moving along a constant avenue (if we suppose that the constant "avenue" is analogous to an electron with constant energy level), would in your alternative axis system be changing both it's X and Y at the same time in a more complex way. And although your alternative axes would still be just as valid for describing the car's motion, it would not let you as easily analyze the avenue of the car (bonding strength of the molecule) as it moves, compared to if you just chose X and Y axes to be aligned with the streets and avenues.  Hope that helps! :)

@ChadsPrep  I have a doubt sir the B.O.(He2)=0 this concludes it forms no bond that's why (He2) doesn't exist but B.O.(Be2) =0 then how does Beryllium forms a dimer and exist.

Great question.  Molecular orbital theory doesn't predict stable dimers for beryllium or for the noble gases as discussed in the video.  But weakly bonded dimers exist not only for beryllium, but for noble gases also!  From the perspective of molecular orbital theory, this was completely unexpected.  It has been accounted for with some advanced quantum mechanics and the interactions are more like van der Waals forces than covalent bonds.  Hope this helps!
